title: Matthew Chapter 5 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Matthew chapter 5 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Matthew Chapter 5 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Matthew Chapter 5.

questions.question: Where did Jesus go when he saw the multitudes according to Matthew 5:1?
questions.correctAnswer: Into a mountain
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:1 states that Jesus went up into a mountain when he saw the multitudes.

questions.question: Who came unto Jesus after he was set on the mountain according to Matthew 5:1?
questions.correctAnswer: His disciples
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:1 explains that Jesus' disciples came unto him after he was set on the mountain.

questions.question: According to Matthew 5:3, who are blessed and what will they inherit?
options: The poor in spirit; the kingdom of heaven
The meek; the kingdom of heaven
The pure in heart; eternal life
questions.correctAnswer: The poor in spirit; the kingdom of heaven
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:3 states that the poor in spirit are blessed because theirs is the kingdom of heaven.

questions.question: According to Matthew 5:5, who will inherit the earth?
questions.correctAnswer: The meek
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:5 says that the meek shall inherit the earth.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Matthew 5:14: 'Ye are the ______ of the world.'
questions.correctAnswer: light
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:14 states, 'Ye are the light of the world.'

questions.question: What did Jesus say about the law and the prophets in Matthew 5:17?
questions.correctAnswer: He came to fulfil them
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:17 clearly states Jesus did not come to destroy the law or the prophets but to fulfil them.

questions.question: True or False: Matthew 5:6 says those who hunger and thirst after righteousness will be filled.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:6 states that those who hunger and thirst after righteousness shall be filled.

questions.question: According to Matthew 5:13, what happens if the salt loses its savour?
questions.correctAnswer: It is good for nothing
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:13 says if the salt loses its savour, it is good for nothing and is cast out.

questions.question: Who shall be called the children of God according to Matthew 5:9?
questions.correctAnswer: The peacemakers
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:9 states that the peacemakers shall be called the children of God.

questions.question: What does Matthew 5:12 say about those who are persecuted for righteousness' sake?
options: They should rejoice because their reward is great in heaven
questions.correctAnswer: They should rejoice because their reward is great in heaven
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:12 encourages rejoicing for those persecuted for righteousness because their reward is great in heaven.

questions.question: True or False: Matthew 5:7 says the merciful shall obtain mercy.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:7 states that the merciful shall obtain mercy.

questions.question: According to Matthew 5:20, whose righteousness must we exceed to enter the kingdom of heaven?
questions.correctAnswer: The scribes and Pharisees
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:20 says your righteousness must exceed that of the scribes and Pharisees to enter the kingdom of heaven.

questions.question: True or False: Matthew 5:38 teaches 'An eye for an eye, and a tooth for a tooth' as the final instruction.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:38 mentions 'An eye for an eye' but then teaches to not resist evil and to turn the other cheek.

questions.question: According to Matthew 5:44, what should you do to those who curse you?
questions.correctAnswer: Bless them
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:44 instructs to bless those who curse you.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Matthew 5:16: 'Let your light so shine before men, that they may see your ______, and glorify your Father which is in heaven.'
questions.correctAnswer: good works
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:16 says let your light shine so that men may see your good works and glorify your Father.

medium.title: Matthew Chapter 5 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Matthew Chapter 5 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer feels discouraged and impoverished in spirit. Based on Matthew 5, what truth would you share to encourage them?
options: Blessed are the poor in spirit, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven
Blessed are the meek, for they shall inherit the earth
Blessed are the merciful, for they shall obtain mercy
Blessed are they that hunger and thirst after righteousness, for they shall be filled
questions.correctAnswer: Blessed are the poor in spirit, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:3 teaches that those who are poor in spirit are blessed because they will receive the kingdom of heaven. This encourages humility and reliance on God. Supporting verses include Matthew 5:4-6, which show blessings for those mourning and hungering for righteousness.

questions.question: How does Matthew 5 teach about forgiveness and reconciliation when offering gifts at the altar?
options: Leave the gift and be reconciled to your brother first, then offer the gift
Offer the gift first, then seek reconciliation afterward
Give the gift only if the brother apologizes first
Reconciliation is not necessary before offering gifts
questions.correctAnswer: Leave the gift and be reconciled to your brother first, then offer the gift
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:23-24 instructs believers to reconcile with their brothers before offering gifts at the altar, emphasizing the priority of peace and forgiveness. This teaches the importance of right relationships in worship. Supporting verses include Matthew 5:9 and 5:25.

questions.question: A believer struggles with anger towards a brother. According to Matthew 5, what is the spiritual danger of such anger?
options: Being in danger of the judgment
questions.correctAnswer: Being in danger of the judgment
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:22 warns that anger without cause toward a brother puts one in danger of judgment. This teaches the seriousness of anger and the need for self-control and reconciliation. Related verses include Matthew 5:21 and 5:23.

questions.question: What practical advice does Matthew 5 give about dealing with personal offenses and legal disputes?
options: Agree quickly with your adversary to avoid harsher consequences
Take your case to the judge as soon as possible
Demand your full rights even if it causes conflict
Ignore the dispute and hope it resolves itself
questions.correctAnswer: Agree quickly with your adversary to avoid harsher consequences
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:25-26 advises believers to settle disputes quickly to avoid judgment and punishment, promoting peace and humility in daily life. This encourages wise conflict resolution. Supporting verses include Matthew 5:23-24.

questions.question: How does Matthew 5 deepen the understanding of adultery beyond the physical act?
options: Looking at a woman to lust after her is adultery in the heart
Only physical adultery counts as sin
Adultery is acceptable if no one finds out
Adultery is not mentioned in Matthew 5
questions.correctAnswer: Looking at a woman to lust after her is adultery in the heart
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:28 teaches that lustful thoughts are equivalent to committing adultery in the heart, emphasizing purity of mind and heart. This calls for spiritual discipline and integrity. Related verses include Matthew 5:27 and 5:29-30.

questions.question: What radical teaching does Matthew 5 give about responding to evil or personal insult?
options: Turn the other cheek when struck on the right cheek
Avoid the person who insults you
Report the insult to authorities immediately
questions.correctAnswer: Turn the other cheek when struck on the right cheek
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:39 instructs believers not to resist evil but to respond with humility and mercy by turning the other cheek, promoting peace and forgiveness. Related verses include Matthew 5:38 and 5:40-41.

questions.question: How does Matthew 5 encourage believers to display their faith publicly and glorify God?
options: Let your light so shine before men that they may see your good works
Keep your faith private and hidden
Avoid showing good works to prevent pride
Only share faith with close family
questions.correctAnswer: Let your light so shine before men that they may see your good works
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:16 encourages believers to let their good works shine publicly so that others may glorify God, highlighting evangelism and witness. Supporting verses include Matthew 5:14-15.

questions.question: According to Matthew 5, what is the consequence of breaking even the least of the commandments and teaching others to do so?
options: He shall be called the least in the kingdom of heaven
He shall be praised by men
He shall be forgiven without consequence
questions.correctAnswer: He shall be called the least in the kingdom of heaven
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:19 teaches that breaking and teaching others to break commandments leads to being called least in the kingdom of heaven, emphasizing obedience and teaching integrity. Related verses include Matthew 5:17-18 and 5:20.

questions.question: True or False: According to Matthew 5, Jesus came to abolish the law and the prophets.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:17 clearly states Jesus did not come to destroy the law or the prophets but to fulfill them, highlighting faithfulness to God's Word.

questions.question: True or False: Matthew 5 teaches that swearing oaths is forbidden for believers.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:34-37 instructs believers not to swear oaths at all, but let their 'Yes' be yes and 'No' be no, promoting honesty and integrity without oath-taking.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'Ye are the ______ of the earth,' teaching believers about their influence in the world.
questions.correctAnswer: salt
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:13 calls believers 'the salt of the earth,' symbolizing their preserving and influencing role in the world. This encourages faithfulness and integrity.

questions.question: How does Matthew 5 instruct believers regarding love for enemies?
options: Love your enemies, bless those who curse you, and pray for those who persecute you
Hate your enemies as the law commands
Ignore your enemies and avoid them
Only love those who love you
questions.correctAnswer: Love your enemies, bless those who curse you, and pray for those who persecute you
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:44 teaches radical love including loving enemies and praying for persecutors, showing the call to imitate God's perfect love (Matthew 5:45, 5:48).

questions.question: A believer is tempted to divorce without cause. How does Matthew 5 guide their understanding of marriage and divorce?
options: Divorcing without cause causes the spouse to commit adultery
Divorce is allowed for any reason
Divorce is not mentioned in Matthew 5
Divorce is encouraged to avoid conflict
questions.correctAnswer: Divorcing without cause causes the spouse to commit adultery
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:31-32 teaches that divorcing except for fornication causes the spouse to commit adultery and marrying a divorced person also commits adultery, emphasizing faithfulness and holiness in marriage.

questions.question: In Matthew 5, what does Jesus say about righteousness compared to that of the scribes and Pharisees?
options: Your righteousness must exceed theirs to enter the kingdom of heaven
Their righteousness is sufficient for salvation
Righteousness is not necessary for the kingdom of heaven
questions.correctAnswer: Your righteousness must exceed theirs to enter the kingdom of heaven
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:20 states that believers' righteousness must surpass that of the scribes and Pharisees, emphasizing sincere obedience and heart transformation.

questions.question: According to Matthew 5, what attitude should a believer have when giving to those who ask or borrow?
options: Give freely and do not turn away those who ask
Give only to those who deserve it
questions.correctAnswer: Give freely and do not turn away those who ask
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:42 encourages generosity by giving to those who ask and not refusing those who want to borrow, teaching stewardship and compassion.

hard.title: Matthew Chapter 5 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Matthew Chapter 5.

questions.question: In Matthew 5:3, Jesus says, 'Blessed are the poor in spirit: for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.' What is the significance of the phrase 'poor in spirit' in the context of Hebrew thought?
options: Those who acknowledge their spiritual need and dependence on God
Those who reject the Law of Moses
questions.correctAnswer: Those who acknowledge their spiritual need and dependence on God
questions.explanation: The term 'poor in spirit' (Matthew 5:3) reflects the Hebrew concept of recognizing one's spiritual bankruptcy and total reliance on God, which is foundational for receiving the kingdom of heaven.

questions.question: Matthew 5:13 states, 'Ye are the salt of the earth.' What cultural and historical significance did salt have in the ancient Near East that enhances the metaphor Jesus used?
options: Salt was a preservative and a valuable seasoning, symbolizing purity and preservation
Salt was used primarily as a currency
Salt was considered unclean and to be avoided
Salt was only used for religious sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: Salt was a preservative and a valuable seasoning, symbolizing purity and preservation
questions.explanation: In the ancient Near East, salt was crucial for preserving food and enhancing flavor, symbolizing the disciples' role in preserving godly values and influencing the world (Matthew 5:13).

questions.question: How does the imagery of 'light' in Matthew 5:14-16 relate to Old Testament themes?
options: It echoes the motif of God as light and the call for His people to reflect that light
It refers to the physical light used in temple rituals
It symbolizes political power over Israel
It represents the fire of judgment only
questions.correctAnswer: It echoes the motif of God as light and the call for His people to reflect that light
questions.explanation: The metaphor of light in Matthew 5:14-16 connects with Old Testament themes where God is light (Psalm 27:1) and His people are called to bear His light before nations.

questions.question: In Matthew 5:17, Jesus says He came not to destroy the Law and the Prophets but to fulfill them. What does 'fulfill' most likely mean in this context?
options: To complete and bring to their intended purpose
questions.correctAnswer: To complete and bring to their intended purpose
questions.explanation: Jesus’ statement in Matthew 5:17 indicates His mission is to bring the Law and the Prophets to full realization, not to nullify them, consistent with Jewish messianic expectations.

questions.question: What literary device is primarily used in the Beatitudes (Matthew 5:3-12) to structure the blessings?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: The Beatitudes use parallelism, a common Hebrew poetic device, pairing a condition with a resulting blessing to emphasize spiritual truths (Matthew 5:3-12).

questions.question: According to Matthew 5:20, Jesus states that righteousness must exceed that of the scribes and Pharisees. What does this imply about the nature of righteousness He is teaching?
options: It must be internal and heartfelt, not merely external compliance
It is solely about legalistic observance
It applies only to priests and leaders
It is based on ritual sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: It must be internal and heartfelt, not merely external compliance
questions.explanation: Jesus emphasizes in Matthew 5:20 that true righteousness surpasses external legalism, pointing to an inward transformation aligned with God’s heart.

questions.question: Matthew 5:21-22 expands the commandment 'Thou shalt not kill.' How does this extension reflect a deeper interpretation of the Law?
options: It addresses the root causes of sin, such as anger and contempt
It permits killing in certain cases
It removes all punishments for anger
It focuses only on legal penalties
questions.correctAnswer: It addresses the root causes of sin, such as anger and contempt
questions.explanation: Jesus' teaching in Matthew 5:21-22 intensifies the Law by addressing the attitudes and emotions that lead to the act of murder, highlighting internal moral responsibility.

questions.question: What is the significance of Jesus instructing to pluck out the right eye or cut off the right hand if they cause one to sin (Matthew 5:29-30)?
options: It is hyperbolic language emphasizing the seriousness of avoiding sin
It suggests complete withdrawal from society
questions.correctAnswer: It is hyperbolic language emphasizing the seriousness of avoiding sin
questions.explanation: The radical language in Matthew 5:29-30 is hyperbole intended to stress the importance of removing anything that causes sin rather than literal self-mutilation.

questions.question: How does Matthew 5:33-37 challenge traditional Jewish oath-taking practices?
options: By instructing to avoid all oaths and let 'Yes' or 'No' be sufficient
By forbidding any form of communication
By mandating oaths only in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: By instructing to avoid all oaths and let 'Yes' or 'No' be sufficient
questions.explanation: Jesus teaches in Matthew 5:33-37 a radical honesty where oaths are unnecessary; simple affirmations suffice, reflecting God's desire for integrity.

questions.question: In Matthew 5:38-42, Jesus teaches to 'turn the other cheek.' How does this teaching contrast with the Old Testament principle of 'an eye for an eye'?
options: It promotes non-retaliation and radical forgiveness rather than strict justice
It permits revenge only under certain conditions
questions.correctAnswer: It promotes non-retaliation and radical forgiveness rather than strict justice
questions.explanation: Jesus contrasts the Old Testament lex talionis with a call to love and forgiveness, encouraging believers to transcend strict retribution (Matthew 5:38-42).

questions.question: Matthew 5:43-44 commands to love your enemies and pray for those who persecute you. Which Old Testament understanding does this challenge?
options: The notion that enemies should be hated or cursed
The command to keep the Sabbath
questions.correctAnswer: The notion that enemies should be hated or cursed
questions.explanation: Jesus challenges the common interpretation of Deuteronomy 23:7 which allowed hatred of enemies, teaching instead radical love (Matthew 5:43-44).

questions.question: What is the theological significance of the phrase 'Be ye therefore perfect, even as your Father which is in heaven is perfect' in Matthew 5:48?
options: It calls for mature moral and spiritual completeness modeled on God's holiness
It demands sinless perfection in the absolute sense
It refers only to ritual purity
questions.correctAnswer: It calls for mature moral and spiritual completeness modeled on God's holiness
questions.explanation: The call to be 'perfect' in Matthew 5:48 is an invitation to reflect God's character and holiness in our lives, emphasizing growth and maturity rather than flawlessness.

questions.question: According to Matthew 5:25-26, why does Jesus advise settling disputes quickly before going to court?
options: To avoid harsher judgment and imprisonment
To show strength in legal battles
questions.correctAnswer: To avoid harsher judgment and imprisonment
questions.explanation: Jesus warns in Matthew 5:25-26 that failing to reconcile may lead to judgment and imprisonment, underscoring the wisdom of peacemaking.

questions.question: True or False: In Matthew 5:10, Jesus promises that those persecuted for righteousness' sake will inherit the kingdom of heaven.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:10 clearly states that those persecuted for righteousness will receive the kingdom of heaven as their reward.

questions.question: How does the Beatitude 'Blessed are the peacemakers: for they shall be called the children of God' (Matthew 5:9) relate to the broader biblical theme of God's nature?
options: It reflects God's identity as a God of peace and reconciliation
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects God's identity as a God of peace and reconciliation
questions.explanation: The Beatitude in Matthew 5:9 aligns with the biblical portrayal of God as a God of peace (Isaiah 9:6), encouraging believers to imitate His reconciling nature.

theological.title: Matthew Chapter 5 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Matthew Chapter 5 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Matthew 5, what is promised to the 'poor in spirit'?
questions.correctAnswer: The kingdom of heaven
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:3 states that 'Blessed are the poor in spirit: for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.' This promise aligns with Isaiah 66:2, where God favors the humble and contrite, and Psalm 34:18 which comforts the brokenhearted. Luke 6:20 also affirms the blessing on the poor. Thus, the kingdom of heaven is promised to those poor in spirit.

questions.question: What does Jesus teach about anger in Matthew 5?
options: Anger without cause can bring judgment
questions.correctAnswer: Anger without cause can bring judgment
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:22 teaches that 'whosoever is angry with his brother without a cause shall be in danger of the judgment.' This expands the commandment against murder (Exodus 20:13) to include unrighteous anger. James 1:19-20 also warns that anger does not produce the righteousness God desires. Ephesians 4:26 advises to be angry but not sin. Thus, unrighteous anger is condemned.

questions.question: In Matthew 5, Jesus says that if your right eye causes you to sin, you should:
options: Pluck it out and cast it from thee
questions.correctAnswer: Pluck it out and cast it from thee
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:29 states 'if thy right eye offend thee, pluck it out, and cast it from thee.' This hyperbolic teaching emphasizes the severity of sin and the necessity of radical action to avoid it, consistent with Paul's teaching in 1 Corinthians 6:18 to flee immorality, and Job 31:1 about guarding the eyes. It underscores the call to holiness.

questions.question: What does Jesus say about the Law and the Prophets in Matthew 5?
questions.correctAnswer: He came to fulfill them
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:17 states 'I am not come to destroy, but to fulfil.' Jesus affirms the continuing validity and fulfillment of the Old Testament Law and Prophets, consistent with Luke 24:44 and Romans 10:4. This shows the continuity of God's redemptive plan through Christ, fulfilling messianic prophecy (Isaiah 53) and the perfect righteousness required by the Law.

questions.question: According to Matthew 5, how should Christians respond to those who persecute them?
options: Love your enemies and pray for them
questions.correctAnswer: Love your enemies and pray for them
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:44 commands to 'Love your enemies, bless them that curse you, do good to them that hate you, and pray for them which despitefully use you.' This radical love reflects God's character (Matthew 5:45), loving both evil and good. Romans 12:20, Luke 6:27-28, and 1 Peter 3:9 reinforce loving and blessing enemies rather than retaliating.

questions.question: What does Jesus say about swearing oaths in Matthew 5?
options: Swear by heaven to confirm truth
questions.correctAnswer: Swear not at all
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:34 states 'But I say unto you, Swear not at all.' Jesus calls for integrity without the need for oaths. This is echoed in James 5:12 and Proverbs 30:8-9 which caution against false oaths and unnecessary vows. The emphasis is on simple, truthful speech: 'Yea, yea; Nay, nay' (Matthew 5:37), reflecting holiness in communication.

questions.question: In Matthew 5, who are called the 'children of God'?
questions.correctAnswer: The peacemakers
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:9 says 'Blessed are the peacemakers: for they shall be called the children of God.' This reflects God's nature as the God of peace (Romans 15:33), and peacemakers emulate His character. Hebrews 12:14 also urges pursuit of peace. This blessing shows the eschatological identity of believers as God's children through Christ (John 1:12).

questions.question: What does Matthew 5 teach about righteousness in relation to entering the kingdom of heaven?
options: Righteousness like the scribes and Pharisees is sufficient
Righteousness must exceed that of the scribes and Pharisees
questions.correctAnswer: Righteousness must exceed that of the scribes and Pharisees
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:20 teaches 'except your righteousness shall exceed the righteousness of the scribes and Pharisees, ye shall in no case enter into the kingdom of heaven.' This implies a deeper, heart-based righteousness rather than mere external observance, consistent with Psalm 51:6 on inner truth, and Jeremiah 31:33 on the new covenant written on hearts. Romans 10:3 contrasts external zeal with true righteousness.

questions.question: According to Matthew 5, what happens to salt that loses its savor?
options: It is still useful for seasoning
It is good for nothing and cast out
questions.correctAnswer: It is good for nothing and cast out
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:13 states 'if the salt have lost his savour... it is thenceforth good for nothing, but to be cast out, and to be trodden under foot of men.' Salt symbolizes believers' preserving and purifying influence (Leviticus 2:13). Losing savor means losing effectiveness, which aligns with Ezekiel 36:26 about a new heart enabling true life. This warns against spiritual ineffectiveness.

questions.question: How does Matthew 5 describe the proper use of light by believers?
options: Let it shine before men to glorify God
Keep it hidden to avoid persecution
Use it only for personal benefit
questions.correctAnswer: Let it shine before men to glorify God
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:16 commands 'Let your light so shine before men, that they may see your good works, and glorify your Father which is in heaven.' This aligns with Psalm 119:105 where God's word is a lamp, and John 8:12 where Jesus is the light of the world. Believers reflect God's glory through holy living, fulfilling Isaiah 60:1's call to arise and shine.

questions.question: What does Jesus teach about divorce in Matthew 5?
options: Divorce is permitted for any reason
Divorce causes adultery except for fornication
questions.correctAnswer: Divorce causes adultery except for fornication
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:32 states 'whosoever shall put away his wife, saving for the cause of fornication, causeth her to commit adultery.' This teaching upholds the sanctity of marriage, consistent with Malachi 2:16 condemning divorce, and Mark 10:11-12 where Jesus reiterates this. It emphasizes faithfulness and the gravity of breaking the marriage covenant.

questions.question: What is the consequence of breaking even the least commandments and teaching others to do so, according to Matthew 5?
options: Being called least in the kingdom of heaven
questions.correctAnswer: Being called least in the kingdom of heaven
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:19 teaches that whoever breaks one of the least commandments and teaches others to do so 'shall be called the least in the kingdom of heaven.' This underscores the seriousness of obeying God's law (Psalm 119:96), and James 2:10 warns that breaking one law makes one guilty of all. It emphasizes faithful teaching and obedience.

questions.question: Which group does Matthew 5 identify as those who will be comforted?
questions.correctAnswer: Those who mourn
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:4 states 'Blessed are they that mourn: for they shall be comforted.' This promise reflects God's compassion (2 Corinthians 1:3-4), and Isaiah 61:2 where God comforts those who grieve. It shows God's care for human suffering and the hope of future consolation.

questions.question: In Matthew 5, Jesus equates looking at a woman with lust to what sin?
questions.correctAnswer: Adultery in the heart
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:28 says 'whosoever looketh on a woman to lust after her hath committed adultery with her already in his heart.' This teaching deepens the commandment against adultery (Exodus 20:14) to include internal desires, consistent with Jeremiah 17:9 on the deceitfulness of the heart, and 1 John 2:16 about lust being sinful. It highlights inward purity.

questions.question: How does Matthew 5 describe those who hunger and thirst after righteousness?
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be filled
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:6 states 'Blessed are they which do hunger and thirst after righteousness: for they shall be filled.' This promise reflects God's provision for those seeking holiness, as in Psalm 107:9, and Isaiah 55:1-2 which invites the thirsty to come for satisfaction. It aligns with the Spirit's work in sanctification (Romans 8:4).
